title: Charles Schwab Eliminates Stock, ETF and Options Commissions
text:
Charles Schwab (SCHW) sent shock waves through the online broker space on Tuesday, announcing that, effective Oct. 7, it would eliminate commissions for stocks, exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and options listed on U.S. and Canadian exchanges.

Schwab, which currently charges a $4.95 commission on U.S. stock, ETF and options trades made online, says the move to zero "across all mobile and web trading channels" is here to stay.

"This is our price. Not a promotion. No catches. Period," founder and Chairman Charles Schwab said in a news release. "Price should never be a barrier to investing for anyone, whether an experienced investor or someone just starting on the investing path."

Options traders, who currently pay an additional 65 cents per contract on top of the $4.95, will continue to pay that fee.

For comparison's sake, E*TRADE (ETFC) and TD Ameritrade (AMTD) currently charge a standard $6.95 for stock, ETF and options trades (plus an additional 75 cents per options contract) made online. Both do offer commission-free trading on some exchange-traded funds.

Schwab, which has no minimum account size to open a brokerage account, says the new pricing scheme will apply to any current web or mobile client, without requiring a new deposit or creating a new account.

While investors who stand to benefit from Schwab's changes may have been celebrating on Tuesday morning, investors in SCHW and other online brokerage companies headed toward the exits. Schwab's stock dipped 9% soon after the open, while AMTD dropped 21% and ETFC declined nearly 18%.

EDITOR'S PICKS

description: Schwab's commissions to vanish Oct. 7; online broker stocks dive in response
